instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.P3V3SUS_EN: What is P3V3SUS_EN? P3V3SUS_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_SUS power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
i have this board with this values
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S40</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.4
I have <SIGNAL>P5V1_BIAS</SIGNAL> in short

advice?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
"I have <SIGNAL>P5V1_BIAS</SIGNAL> in short"
Exact ohm value?
Compare with the values on <CAPACITOR>C7100</CAPACITOR>/1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message: veleus are same 0.12

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
You've said to have short at pin <SIGNAL>5V1_BIAS</SIGNAL>.
<RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR> is burnt?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message: aesthetically it doesn't look burnt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
So, do you have short there???
Already asked that, didn't get any reply...

Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
i have short in <RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR>
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
pin 1=0v
pin 2 = 0.2v
pin 3 =0.2
pin 9=0v
pin 12=3.4
pin 13=3.3
pin 14=0
pin 15=0.1
pin 17=0
pin 19=4.8
pin 20=5.3
pin 27=0
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is very hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> diode mode to ground now; pins 2, 12, 17, 19, 20, 27.

"i have short in <RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR>"
Which pad to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
pin 2=0.160
pin 12=330
pin17=0.150
pin 19=0.063
pin 20=0.064
pin 26=0.717
<RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR> ground in pin 1-2

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR> goes to pin 20 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
How don't you get ground there too??
However, 0.063 is not good; change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Check in diode mode again, once <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is removed (before resolder it).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
i replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, now i have orange led and i no longer have short on <RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR>
but it still won't turn on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7191</RESISTOR> is still good, not blown?

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=0.5
the coil looks perfect

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power

threads.message:
pin23=12.5V
pin22=3.3V
pin12=3.4V
pin13=1.9V
pin29=5V
pin21=3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
Are you sure no voltage at L7560?
Check diode mode to ground there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
L7569=3.3V
in diode mode 0.147

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
I suppose you've meant L7560.

"<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=0.5"
What's this then???
PLEASE, post accurate information.

I ask again, do you have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> seems to be OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>=3.3
sorry 7560=3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
What happened from yesterday?
"<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL>=0
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>=0.5"

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>= from3.4v at 0.420v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time.
If yes, also check for pulse on al all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=0
now I no longer have any orange light and the bench power supply shows me 0.05
